list_definition.definition: one part of a house or building, usually used for a particular purpose
the space or area in which a person, thing etc is or could be put etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The bed takes up a lot of room
There’s no room for you in our car
We’ll move the bookcase to make room for the television.
There is room for improvement in his work.

list_ex_of_english: Tenants could retreat to the privacy of their own rooms, but even here they were often expected to share, especially if they were related.
One might venture that the new science either responded to or was influenced by trends in opera houses and concert rooms.
The members are expected simply to listen to what is discussed in committee rooms and to follow their party's direction.
In a period when population growth came up against regulatory limits on new building, the partition of existing houses into smaller rooms was commonplace.
Such houses are highly subdivided, with kitchens, dining rooms, several bedrooms, and other elements common to the large modern house.
Genial rehearsal rooms may be pleasant to be in, but they rarely spark significant work in my experience.
The program took place in specially designed work-out rooms located at the hospital and was carried out in the mornings.
According to the representatives of the town council the different rooms are described and measured in bays, from north to south.
